node.text: As we chart the path forward, women and girls are playing a critical role in reimagining and rebuilding our world. Celebrate Women’s History Month and watch this film from @VitalVoices, featuring my poem 'Vital Voices' - calling us all to rise. https://youtu.be/vzFoLxkq5Gs

node.text: So grateful for the opportunity to honor three change-makers at the Super Bowl. Crafting a 90 second poem that celebrates three distinct heroes, each with their own inspiring life story, certainly was difficult, but more than worth the challenge. I so enjoyed researching and learning more about these three captains over the past two months. Thanks for tuning in and sharing, and who knows: maybe next year I’ll see you at half-time ;) (Stylist @jasonbolden )

node.title: Super Bowl Poem  Chorus of the Captains

node.text: Wow, we’re about to see poetry at the Super Bowl for the first time people. It’s a turning page for poetry,  for art, and for our country, because it means we’re thinking more imaginatively about the power of human stories, more expansively about the ways to connect us even when we feel more siloed than ever. What’s more, I can’t tell you how many people I’ve heard say they are excited to watch the Super Bowl because there will be poetry at it. What a thrilling moment we live in, when we are so eager to celebrate art, hope and each other. Today I have the distinct privilege of honoring three heroes who exemplify the absolute best of humanity. Here’s to them. Here’s to poetry. Here’s to a Super Bowl like no other. (Video @thedailyshow )

node.title: The First Super Bowl Poet Ever

node.text:
“I don’t think I always knew I was going to be the Inaugural poet, but every single time I wrote a public poem, before I began writing it, I would tell myself: write a poem that is worthy of a presidential inauguration,” Gorman says in a video interview shot during her cover shoot. Sitting just feet away from the 22-year-old on Inauguration Day was former First Lady @michelleobama—who had met Gorman twice before. In a remote interview, the two covered topics ranging from the role of art in activism to the pressures Black women face in the spotlight. Read their full conversation at the link in bio. 
Repost @time 
Video by @spencerbakalar, @paulmoakley, @adamperez22 and Rose Cohn (@rosepwn) for TIME

node.text:
Can’t believe it’s been two years since this came out! Thank you to @kiraktv and @cbsthismorning for this amazing opportunity as well as the several we’ve worked on together since.
At first I was terrified to pen a piece about a holiday that was fraught with such a history of colonialism and genocide. But I felt the poem was worth writing if it could call attention to what various indigenous American value systems have to teach us all about gratitude--namely that giving thanks isn’t an annual day, but actions woven into our daily life that contribute to something larger than ourselves. While for some today is a celebration, for others it is a rightful day of collective mourning. This is a lesson to be learned, and a question to ask ourselves: What do we have that we have taken for granted? And how can I give that away in honor of those whose land I stand on, in service of my people and my planet?

In this spirit, I’m starting off my day donating to some of these organizations I love: @natifs_org , which addresses the economic and health crises affecting Native communities by re-establishing Native foodways. 

Another thanks we can give is to the farm workers who continue to provide us with food. Donations can be made to @ufwf , which promotes the dignity of our farmworkers.

How are you giving back and do you have organization recommendations? Comment below!

node.text:
THE 👏🏿TIME 👏🏿HAS 👏🏿COME. Today @cbsthismorning shared my new poem, Fury and Faith, an ode to all the black lives we’ve lost, and a rallying cry to all the fighters that are still standing up. 
Thanks @caaminla for letting us film at your  @crosscoloursla exhibit, & producers @spinderc and @kiraktv
#blacklivesmatter

FURY AND FAITH
Fury and Faith

You will be told this is not a problem, 
Not your problem. 
You will be told now is not the time 
For change to begin, 
Told that we cannot win.

But the point of protest isn’t winning; 
It’s holding fast to the promise of freedom, 
Even when fast victory is not promised. 
Meaning, we cannot stand up to police, 
If we cannot cease policing ourselves,
Convincing our communities that this won’t work, 
When the work hasn't even begun,
That this can wait, 
When we’ve already waited out a thousand suns.
By now, we understand
That white supremacy and 
The despair it demands 
Are destructive as any disease.

So when you’re told that your rage is reactionary, 
Remind yourself that rage is our right. 
It teaches us it is time to fight.
In the face of injustice, 
Not only is anger natural, but necessary,
Because it helps carry us to our destination. 
Our goal is never revenge, just restoration. 
Not dominance, just dignity. 
Not fear, just freedom. 
Just justice.

Whether we prevail is not determined 
By all the challenges that are present, 
But by all the change that is possible.

And though we are unstoppable,
If we ever feel we might fail,
If we be fatigued and frail,
When our fire can no longer be fueled by fury, 
We will always be fortified by this faith, 
Found in the anthem, the vow:
All Black lives matter. 
Black lives are worth living, 
Worth defending

Worth every struggle. 
We owe it to the fallen to fight,
We owe it to ourselves to never stay kneeling 
When the day calls us to stand. 
Together, we envision a land that is liberated, not lawless.
We create a future that is free, not flawless.
Again and again, over and over, 
We will stride up every mountains ide, 
Magnanimous and modest.
We will be protected and served 
By a force that is honored and honest. 
This is more than protest. It’s a promise

node.text:
It’s an honor to be the @wsjmag cover woman of their latest issue! Special shout out to @cassblackbird for making this such a fun shoot. Read about my conversation with @clovito via the link in my bio, where we discussed the intersection of art and politics, experiences that shaped me, and my new book, Call Us What We Carry, which releases this December 7th!

Writer: @clovito Photographer: @cassblackbird Subject: @amandascgorman Fashion: @jasonbolden Hair: @itsraela Makeup: @joannasimkin Manicure: @nails_by_yoko Video: @barbaranastacio Special Projects: @specialprojectsmedia

May be an image of text that says 'Amanda Gorman @TheAmandaGorman As Afghanistan suffers, America has to take a long look at how we've perpetuated horror & how we can provide healing. We must welcome refugees & at last become the country we say we are. Today is the day to take in the tired, the poor, the huddled masses yearning to breathe free.'.

node.text:
@vitalvoices , an organization that funded me as a young activist, has now expanded its Voices Against Violence Initiative and Urgent Assistance Fund to get immediate support out to women activists in Afghanistan on the frontlines of change and to ensure that survivors of gender-based violence (GBV) and harmful practices have better access to services, protection and the justice they deserve. 
‼️Donations in the next 48 hours are critical and can save lives. Let’s get these women and their families out ASAP🚨🇦🇫

node.text:
Californians, it’s time to vote and have our voices heard. Put it in your calendar and make a voting plan! 🗓

Repost @iamavoter 

On September 14, California voters will participate in a recall election for Governor Gavin Newsom. Every registered CA voter will get a ballot in the mail. Voters can vote by mail, in person, or by dropping their ballot in a dropbox. 

For more information on how the California Recall Election works, see our Stories today. And tag a California voter below to remind them about these key dates! #iamavoter

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amanda Gorman on August 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says '40x40 ARCHEWELL.COM/40X40'.

node.text: To celebrate the 40th birthday of my friend Meghan, The Duchess of Sussex, I’m donating 40 minutes of mentorship to a woman reentering the workforce. Will you join me? Tens of millions of women around the world have lost jobs during the pandemic. If you can commit 40 minutes to community service or mentorship today, we can help ignite a global wave of compassion and change. #40x40 #CompassionInAction

node.text:
I’m so excited to reveal the cover (and final title!) for my new poetry collection, Call Us What We Carry. These poems explore hope, grief, and healing and I can’t wait to share them with the world on December 7th! You can preorder from the link in my bio #CallUsWhatWeCarry 
📸 @kelianne

node.text:
Thrilled to be the @portermagazine cover star! It’s particularly meaningful as not too long ago I was a @portermagazine Incredible Girl, which meant @netaporter was one of the first major magazines to list my name on the cover when not nearly as many people knew who I was. I remember holding (more like clutching) the issue while catching a flight at Heathrow. The climb’s gotta start somewhere, and wow has mine been so blessed.
LINK IN BIO

@portermagazine by @netaporter

 @internetbby
✍🏾 @kadishmorris
Glam:
Styled by @jasonbolden
MAU @joannnasimkin
Hair by @Lacyredway / @itsraela
Nails by @nails_by_yoko 

REPOST

Our latest cover star @amandascgorman has had a whirlwind six months, after she was propelled to global stardom during her spellbinding spoken-word performance at the presidential inauguration. The poet speaks to @kadishmorris about how her life has changed; growing up in LA with her mother and equally “smart and creative” twin sister, filmmaker @thegabriellegorman; being asked to co-chair the Met Gala alongside @tchalamet, @billieeilish and @naomiosaka (“It feels like being a freshman at a party with seniors!”); and her own political ambitions. “Before I think, ‘Should I run for office?’ it starts with [me asking], what is it about office that needs to be changed?” At the link in bio, read the full interview and discover the full shoot, shot by @internetbby, styled by @jasonbolden

May be a cartoon of text that says 'BRight WE MUSIC SERIES ANETFLIX THE PEOPLE H.E.R. Bebe REXHA Brandi CARLILE Janelle MONÁE CORDAE Adam LAMBERT Andra DAY Lin-Manuel MIRANDA Brittany HOWARD Daveed DIGGS Kristen ANDERSON-LOPEZ Robert LOPEZ KYLE Amanda GORMAN JULY'.

node.text: This 4th of July I’m so grateful to be part of @netflix We the People, a musical series on civics and government executive produced by @barackobama & @michelleobama . When I heard about this project it was an instant yes, and it was amazing working with this talented team (and the incomparable @chrisnee4660 ) to transform my poem The Miracle of Morning into an animated short. Hope you enjoy watching it as much as we enjoyed making it. 🇺🇸🎆🎇

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amanda Gorman on June 16, 2021. May be a Twitter screenshot of text that says 'Amanda Gorman @TheAmandaGorman That was me until two years ago. You don't have to be able to say world to be able to change it justjenperiod @justjen... 5/7/21 Replying to @TheAmandaGorman As someone who can't say the word "world" because the /r and and/ /I are too damn close together. You and your world-renowned speech bring me so much joy.'.

node.text: Sharing this here because I want anyone with speech issues to know it. 💛☀️This place needs your one and only voice.
